description: From Latin exsecrārī, execrārī, from ex (“out”) + sacrāre (“to consecrate, declare accursed”).

verbs.description: execrate (third-person singular simple present execrates, present participle execrating, simple past and past participle execrated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to feel loathing for; to abhor
examples: And were I not a thing for you and me  To execrate in angish, you would be  As indigent a stranger to surprise,  I fear, as I was once, and as unwise.

entries.meaning: (transitive) to declare to be hateful or abhorrent; to denounce
examples: Synonyms: anathematize, comminate, curse, damn, imprecate, maledict, obdurate

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) to invoke a curse; to curse or swear
